original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished:
Time seems to slip through my fingers—another week has passed in the blink of an eye. Yesterday, as I passed by our soon-to-be home, I noticed the front window obscured by stacks of boxes, a tangible sign of the new chapter ahead. The anticipation is thrilling; if everything proceeds smoothly this week, we'll finalize the purchase a week from Wednesday.  

Last night stretched into the early hours as Bethany and I indulged in a movie marathon—a common pastime for us lately. Our lineup? First, *Thirteen*, a raw and eye-opening film that every parent of a teenager ought to watch. It surpassed my expectations. Then, out of sheer curiosity, we subjected ourselves to *Gigli*. The critics weren’t wrong—it was every bit as disappointing as reported—but sometimes, you just have to see for yourself.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished:
Summer television was once a barren landscape of reruns and lackluster programming. However, this season has brought two exceptional new series that have captivated me over the past week.  

*Blow Out* presents the most ironically gay premise imaginable, yet features surprisingly few LGBTQ+ characters. The show follows celebrity hairstylist Jonathan Antin as he attempts to expand his wildly successful West Hollywood salon by opening a second location in Beverly Hills. Under normal circumstances, this venture would hardly warrant attention—least of all mine. But while channel-surfing, I caught a fleeting glimpse of Jonathan, radiating equal parts narcissism and tedium, as he stood in an empty Rodeo Drive storefront and dramatically proclaimed (in his best public voice), *"I will create the greatest salon the world has ever seen!"*  

And just like that, I was hooked. Not since *The Rocco DiSpirito Show* have I encountered such a mesmerizingly insufferable figure on television.

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished:
This past week has been incredibly challenging. I've been struggling with tendonitis in my right shoulder, specifically beneath my shoulder blade. The pain becomes excruciating whenever I overuse my arm—particularly during prolonged computer work with a mouse. My recent marathon sessions updating my website and handling online projects have left me barely able to move it now. The discomfort has sapped my energy to the point where even drawing feels nearly impossible. Compounding matters, sleep deprivation has intensified the pain.  

While I'm admittedly feeling low at the moment, I know this is temporary, and I'll recover. On a brighter note, my mother's surgery went well, and there's been some progress with her vision—she can now distinguish blurred shapes and colors. However, her sight remains severely impaired. We're hopeful her vision will continue to improve in the coming days.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished:
The kindness of strangers never ceases to amaze me. Today's laundry adventure with my children in tow became a vivid reminder of how mundane tasks can swiftly transform into chaotic challenges. Yet amidst the chaos, I discovered something beautiful—the unexpected warmth of strangers who offered help simply because they wanted to. Let me be clear: this wasn't some ulterior-motivated gesture. Between the toddler drool stains and my disheveled laundry-day attire, I was far from alluring. Frankly, with my current hygiene standards, there wasn't even a faint scent-based incentive!  

At this moment, I'm multitasking at my desk—crafting this post while nostalgically watching No Doubt's greatest hits. The perfect soundtrack for reflecting on life's small but meaningful moments.

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished:
It's 11:14 PM Mountain Standard Time, and I'm seated in my bedroom repairing the personal computer belonging to my workplace's personnel director. While I don't particularly object to helping, I occasionally reflect on how frequently I end up troubleshooting others' computers as a favor. I genuinely appreciate being able to serve and care for people through this skill, but I often question where to draw the line between kindness and being exploited.  

Recently, I've been burning the midnight oil with reading and other activities, so I was eager to turn in early tonight—until practicality prevailed, reminding me it would be wiser to return this computer to its owner sooner rather than later. *Chuckles* It seems there's little respite for those who are perpetually busy. And so, here I am, rewatching *Joe Schmo 2* to pass the time.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished: Could you remind me what I wrote about previously? Alternatively, let me continue the 'Is this a date?' saga. Following that awkward lunch encounter, my confidence took a hit—I neglected to mention a crucial detail earlier. Before Pat arrived, Dustin began praising him as such a great guy and openly discussed his mission to find Pat a girlfriend. As I listened and nodded along, it dawned on me that the conversation revolved more around matchmaking for Dustin's best friend than the usual small talk one expects when meeting a stranger over pink lemonade. I stepped away to the restroom, caught my reflection in the mirror, and quietly wondered: Am I being passed off to his friend? Is this really how things unfold now?

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: Let us all embrace the practice of mindful deliberation before taking action. In fact, I sincerely hope that every individual on this planet begins each day with conscious thought and maintains that awareness throughout their waking hours. Those unwilling to engage in such basic cognitive effort would do well to remain in bed indefinitely. The prevalence of thoughtless behavior has become intolerable. While I certainly don't claim superior intellect, I'm referring to matters requiring minimal mental effort—making willful ignorance particularly inexcusable. For now, I'll focus my critique on specific categories of foolishness, reserving other observations for future discussion. This seems a reasonable approach, does it not?

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished:
The scenario I described earlier presents two critical flaws:  

First, while President Bush's economic stimulus measures may provide short-term relief, their design is fundamentally misguided. As former Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin noted in a recent NPR Marketplace interview, the administration could have achieved comparable economic stimulation through targeted, temporary tax cuts for low- and middle-income earners—avoiding the long-term fiscal burden of permanent cuts. Rubin’s expertise stands in stark contrast to the current administration’s domestic policy leadership, which lacks comparable depth and credibility.  

Second, the argument that Republicans should govern exclusively during wartime is untenable, given their deliberate framing of an indefinite, borderless "War on Terror." This rhetorical strategy effectively manufactures perpetual justification for their political dominance, undermining democratic accountability.

original: 'she's saying i'm on the run, i'm chasing guys for fun' ~the offspring umm haven't updated in awhile but not much to say.. Went to the cove to see supernothing, they were good as usual, got to chill with tiago :-).. Sat. Went to work and then out w/ joe and rach, met up with steve, tiago and tom.. Came home at like quarter to 12 and woke up the next morning at quarter to 7 for a meet.. Got there a little late but it's all good, i did my full on floor and didn't fall, second on floor and vault and third on beam, 29.45 all around which isn't bad bc my meets get better as the season goes on..
polished:
Lyrics from The Offspring's song echo in my mind: 'She's saying I'm on the run, I'm chasing guys for fun.' It's been a while since my last update, though there hasn't been much to share. Recently, I went to The Cove to catch Supernothing's performance—they delivered their usual excellent show, and I had the pleasure of hanging out with Tiago.  

On Saturday, I worked during the day before meeting up with Joe and Rach later. We were joined by Steve, Tiago, and Tom for the evening. I returned home around 11:45 PM, only to wake up early the next morning at 6:45 AM for a gymnastics meet. Although I arrived slightly late, everything went smoothly—I performed my full floor routine without any falls, placed second on both floor and vault, and took third on beam. My all-around score of 29.45 is decent, especially considering I typically improve as the season progresses.

original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished:
Have you ever experienced that surreal moment of introspection, where your mind drifts from mundane reality to profound existential questions? Picture this: you're trapped in a monotonous math lecture, your consciousness detaching as you ponder the very mechanisms of thought that allow you to comprehend equations. In this strange epiphany, you become acutely aware of your own existence—here, now, in this classroom—and question the meaning behind it all. The sheer wonder of being alive washes over you... only to be undercut by the crushing realization that such philosophical musings during basic algebra are frankly ridiculous.  

And while we're discussing academic grievances, let's address the true atrocity: block scheduling. Whoever devised this torturous system clearly never endured the agony of a 150-minute lecture on any subject. It's nothing short of institutionalized cruelty.

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished:
I believe my time with Monopoly has reached its natural conclusion, and I solemnly swear to never touch that cursed game piece (not the hot iron, but the metal token) again. Tonight, Andy narrowly defeated me by a mere few dollars in the final round—or perhaps I allowed him to win, considering he departs in just a few hours and I wanted him to leave on a positive note. Regardless of how it unfolded, none of it compares to the crushing headache I'm battling now. Thankfully, the Aleve I took is working its magic, and all I need now is some well-earned rest.  

*'Your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck...'* — At the Drive-In

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. First off i have to say that camp was awesome and even better than i could have expected. God's been doing so much stuff in my life lately and it's just awesome. I've sort of turned over a new leaf i guess, but anyway's back to the beginning. We arrived at the twiggs' house on friday evening and we stayed until we left for camp on monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, walmart and watched movies.
polished:
Today has been an exhausting yet fulfilling day. After our long journey back from Indiana, I find myself needing to be selective about what I share, as recounting everything would require more time and energy than I currently possess.  

First and foremost, I must express how incredible the camp experience was—it surpassed all my expectations. Recently, God has been working profoundly in my life, and the transformation has been nothing short of remarkable. It feels as though I've started a new chapter.  

To rewind, our trip began when we arrived at the Twiggs' house on Friday evening. We stayed there until Monday, when we departed for camp. During our time with them, we enjoyed a variety of activities, including visiting the fair, attending church, watching a parade, shopping at Walmart, and relaxing with movies. Each moment contributed to an unforgettable experience.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished:
Today marks the bittersweet end of my summer break—how I wish it could last longer! To make matters worse, I have an early dental appointment at 9 AM, which I’m dreading. Still, I suppose it’s better to endure it now than to juggle scheduling conflicts during the demanding first month of my surgery rotation.  

The thought of returning to school fills me with palpable anxiety—nervousness, fear, restlessness, you name it. Every synonym for "I absolutely do not want to go" applies here. This next chapter will be entirely unfamiliar territory, and while I thrive on excelling in everything I do as a perfectionist, stepping into the unknown is undeniably daunting.  

I loathe feeling like a mere pawn, powerless and constrained. As I told Cassie, "I’ll be the one pawn stubbornly trying to move like a knight." Worse still is the frustration of navigating uncertainty, of not having control or clarity. Here’s to facing the challenge, reluctant as I may be.

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Arun Shourie highlights how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh, T.V. Rajeswar—formerly the head of the Intelligence Bureau—had foreseen the alarming possibility of a 'Third Islamic State' emerging in the subcontinent as early as 1996. Rajeswar articulated these grave concerns in a series of articles published in *The Hindustan Times* at the time. Shourie poses a thought-provoking question: Does the revelation that Rajeswar, rather than himself or figures like Mr. Advani, authored these warnings lend them greater credibility? Or does it instead invite the unfair dismissal of Rajeswar as a covert communalist, unworthy of his gubernatorial position?

original: Attitude: bored mood: indifferent, looking forward to tonight been a long hard day in the trenches here today folks, almost no time to write anything for you readers. However it's good to see tigger(now akcron) taking up the reigns herself and making an appearance and talking about things :) not much to say about things, yesterday was shakespeare on the green, was a lovely play, but i had to leave before closing curtain, which kinda sucked, hopefully someday i'll see the entirety of a shakespeare play. But i digress. Akcron is right about the problems with the shower, it sucks, in terms of laughing at her in the shower, you have to admit, the look people get when committing self torture can be pretty entertaining.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

Today has been exhausting—spent entirely immersed in work, leaving little opportunity to share much with you all. Still, it’s refreshing to see Tigger (now Akcron) stepping up, engaging with the community, and sharing her thoughts.  

Yesterday’s highlight was *Shakespeare on the Green*. The performance was delightful, though I regret having to leave before the finale. Someday, I hope to experience a full Shakespearean production uninterrupted.  

On another note, Akcron’s complaints about the shower are entirely justified—it’s far from ideal. That said, there’s an undeniable humor in witnessing someone endure such an ordeal. The expressions alone can be quite amusing.

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished:
Without warning, an overwhelming fatigue has consumed me for the past two days—a deep, bone-weary exhaustion. Yesterday evening, I returned home and collapsed into sleep, only rousing when my mother called me at half past eight. Upon waking in the pitch-black room, disoriented and struggling to grasp reality, her voice was the only anchor in those fleeting moments of confusion. I can't fathom why I feel so utterly drained...  

The morning brought pleasant weather—a light drizzle as I arrived. Meanwhile, I hear Calcutta has endured three straight days of rain.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished: Last night was utterly disastrous. I ended up discarding the sweater I'd been painstakingly knitting, despite having completed nearly 14 inches of work. The financial loss stings—approximately $10 worth of premium yarn (priced at $8 per skein)—but the real frustration lay in the craftsmanship. By the time I reached the armholes, the stitch count was hopelessly off, and the mohair yarn kept tangling into impossible knots with every row. Attempting to frog the project (undoing rows to correct mistakes) proved futile as the delicate fibers kept snapping. Remarkably, I didn't even curse—a rare display of restraint for me. Instead, I quietly unraveled my work to the soundtrack of *Sex and the City*'s second season (thank goodness for library rentals). Eventually, my patience wore thin, and the entire project met its end in the trash. While disheartening, I suppose the experience wasn't entirely wasted—I certainly learned valuable lessons about yarn selection and pattern precision.

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: During last evening's seminar, we engaged in a thoughtful discussion about Edward S. Casey's seminal work, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World*. The text's opening chapter examines the concept of "implacement," while the subsequent section explores "displacement." Casey presents a compelling argument in the initial chapter, contrasting our modern temporal-centric worldview—with its pervasive notions of time scarcity, efficiency, and punctuality—with his proposed paradigm that positions place as the fundamental organizing principle of culture. This spatial framework, he contends, fosters more rooted and cohesive communities. (I offer this as a broad interpretation—should my professor or peers encounter this reflection, I acknowledge it as a simplified overview.) Among our assigned readings, Casey's work stands out as the first to truly captivate me, offering what feels like an intellectual awakening.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.
polished: The vibrant dyes used in freeze pops should come with a disclaimer: "May induce delightful absurdity into your life." While laughter is welcome, one can't help but question whether we'd have ended up perched on a fire escape, braving gusty winds with beers in hand, had we not consumed those technicolor treats earlier. Our adventure led us to the shuttered entrance of a closed bar, where we paused to leaf through a newly delivered office supplies catalog—a fortunate decision indeed. Who could have imagined such mundane pages concealed once-in-a-lifetime deals? Certainly not me. Among the treasures: a free stunt kite with 36 permanent markers, or a complimentary barbecue with 30 lever arch files. The universe works in mysterious ways.

original: Currently listening to: the little drummer boy by stevan pasero ...and now my post... Senate republicans okay, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations wankathon last week? i know i didn't. Well, okay - i did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was perpetrated by republicans who, pissed off that democrats wouldn't roll over and nominate four of bush's nutjob justices, were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day cry-fest. Never mind the fact that the democrats have already approved 168 of bush's judicial nominees - nooo, that's not good enough for the power-mad republicans who are for some reason laboring under the misapprehension they have a huge mandate for this kind of nonsense.
polished:
**Refined Version:**  

*Currently enjoying:* "The Little Drummer Boy" by Stevan Pasero... Now, to my thoughts.  

Senate Republicans, let’s be honest—who among you actually watched last week’s 39-hour judicial nomination spectacle? I’ll admit, I only caught glimpses of it. This exhausting display was orchestrated by Republicans, frustrated that Democrats refused to rubber-stamp four of Bush’s controversial judicial picks. Instead of constructive dialogue, they staged a prolonged political tantrum.  

Never mind that Democrats have already confirmed 168 of Bush’s nominees—apparently, that wasn’t sufficient for Republicans, who seem to believe they have an overwhelming mandate for such theatrics. The entire ordeal was nothing more than a wasteful exercise in partisan grandstanding.

original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished:
This past weekend proved remarkably fulfilling. I indulged generously in cannabis after an extended hiatus, rediscovered the musical brilliance of Nevermore (a long-overdue rediscovery), and immersed myself in literature. I completed three noteworthy works: Bruce Sterling's *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven's *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler's *Parable of the Sower*.  

Sterling's *Heavy Weather* offers a gripping cyberpunk journey through a near-future United States ravaged by climate catastrophe and societal collapse. Though the novel excels in its sharp pacing, inventive premise, and unsettling plausibility, I found myself somewhat detached from its narrative and characters by the conclusion. This isn't to say the craftsmanship falters—the world-building is vivid, the prose deft—but the experience, while thoroughly engaging, didn't resonate with me on a deeper level. A compelling read, certainly, but not an unforgettable one.

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished:
The aftermath of returning from practicum proved challenging, with the first week being particularly difficult. However, by the second week, clarity began to emerge. What became evident is that post-practicum trauma is a widespread yet overlooked issue only now gaining recognition.  

Initially overwhelmed, I found relief after meeting with the course coordinator, where I shared my concerns. This not only lightened my burden but also helped prevent another student from facing the same pedagogically inadequate practicum environment.  

Just yesterday, I encountered a distressed classmate who was adamant about warning the next student assigned to her problematic school. I reassured her and suggested we first address the issue with the administration rather than acting impulsively.

original: Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress relieving activities. I've found that i really suck at 8-ball and ping pong! rick(the canuck) beats my ass on a regular basis - we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, always time for a 'quick round'. Last night i participated in an 8-ball tournament over at the hot spot (our recreation tent - complete with popcorn machine, numerous tv's, jukebox, dvd rental, pool table, dart board, and ever present ping pong table). Anyway, i was doing pretty well throughout my one entire game - until i scratched on the eight ball ;( i still had a fairly good time - the most fun was the two dutch soldiers that joined in the tournament.
polished:
Life here can get overwhelmingly hectic at times, but I always make room for activities that supposedly relieve stress—though I've discovered I'm remarkably unskilled at both 8-ball and ping pong. Rick (the Canadian) routinely defeats me; we often squeeze in quick matches at the ping pong table in our building's lobby.  

Last night, I competed in an 8-ball tournament at "The Hot Spot"—our recreation tent equipped with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, dartboard, and, of course, the ever-present ping pong table. I was holding my own for most of my first game—until I scratched on the eight ball. Despite that, I had a great time, especially thanks to the two Dutch soldiers who joined the tournament and made it even more entertaining.

original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished:
**Autumn 1974:** For what seemed like the thirteenth attempt, I was wrestling with the second chapter of my high school algebra textbook. Mathematics and I have never been on good terms—then or now. Numbers terrify me; equations feel like hieroglyphics. You understand the struggle.  

Just as I was piecing together a fragile thread of comprehension, the doorbell chimed. Reluctantly, I set aside my book and answered—only to find emptiness. Perfect.  

I returned to my work, and as that elusive spark of understanding flickered in my mind, the bell rang again. *Snap.* The moment shattered. Another futile trip to the door confirmed it: no one. Exactly the distraction a frustrated student *doesn’t* need—some anonymous prankster toying with my patience.

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, these are the things i need to consider as i spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: The past seven days have been utterly draining. From Tuesday through Thursday, I was completely immersed in relocating to my new classroom. While the space is more spacious and conveniently located near my grade-level colleagues—key factors that influenced my decision—the transition required countless hours of preparation. Had I been informed about this move before the academic year concluded, I would have disposed of numerous outdated books and unused materials. Instead, I found myself transporting everything, resulting in a week filled with hauling boxes, unpacking, and ruthlessly decluttering. I’m incredibly grateful to my teammate Jill, who went above and beyond to assist me despite still teaching in my former classroom this month. Remarkably, she and her wonderful students handled nearly the entire move for me!

original: You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if i never carried you child, even if i was never married to you, even if i was never an official pair to you ... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling carries an echo through my heart. Forever will i always be reminded of the very few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach ... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever i get the feeling of a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me ... And still remains. .. For heri
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

Though fate denied us the bonds of marriage or children, though we were never bound by vows or titles, a part of you will forever dwell within me. My love for you was boundless, and its echo lingers still—a quiet, persistent whisper in my heart.  

I will always cherish those fleeting nights when we were one, our bodies and souls intertwined beneath the vast, starlit sky by the shore, or the memory of your lips meeting mine in the rain. Even now, when sorrow pierces me like shards of dark glass, you are there—that fragment of you, alive within me, bleeding the love that once burned so fiercely… and never truly faded.  

For her.

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.
polished: Investigative journalism leaves me deeply unsettled—or more precisely, the implications of this article I'm working on trouble me. My discomfort may stem from a lack of conviction, an inability to fully embrace the fervor and relentless inquiry that drives it. Growing up in a place where questions were met with bullets or imprisonment under draconian laws has conditioned me to silence. This freedom to speak openly, to challenge without fear—it feels foreign, almost dangerous. Admittedly, I’ve never been one for easy conformity.

original: We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We went to guintubdan, la carolota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked for the falls. It was a 30 minute or so walk. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. The water was chilly ice. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. We only stayed less than an hour because we headed for the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it because the falls looked calming and the whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you be lulled to sleep.
polished:
Yesterday, my colleagues from the bank and I embarked on a memorable outing to Guintubdan in La Carlota. For most of us, it was our first visit to this breathtaking destination. Our adventure began with a challenging 30-minute trek to the waterfalls, leaving us breathless yet exhilarated upon arrival. The glacial waters sent shivers through our bodies, their icy embrace gradually numbing our senses. After a brief stay, we ventured onward to another nearby cascade, enduring another half-hour hike through lush terrain.  

The effort proved utterly worthwhile. The cascading waters exuded serenity, their majestic beauty rendering us speechless. Standing there, surrounded by nature’s splendor, I felt an overwhelming sense of harmony—as if the rustling leaves and rushing waters whispered secrets of the earth. Submerging myself in the frigid pool felt like a sacred communion with nature itself. The crisp air and chilling waters wove a tranquil spell, lulling me into a state of blissful repose. It was an experience that rejuvenated both body and soul.

original: Well i am sure my sisters are drunk off their butts. Today was pride in san diego. I know my sisters and when it is drinking time, it is drinking time. It is the one thing i didn't get from the buenviajes, the want to drink. There are few times i don't mind drinking but let's just say they are very rare times. I’m certain my sisters are completely intoxicated by now. Today was Pride in San Diego, and knowing them, when there’s an opportunity to drink, they take full advantage. That’s one trait I didn’t inherit from the Buenviajes—their enthusiasm for alcohol. While I occasionally don’t mind a drink, those moments are exceedingly rare.  

We now have just one month left before Ed departs, and the reality of his leaving is beginning to settle in for him—and for all of us. Personally, I came to terms with it long ago. My only hope is that he’ll still be here for Bailey’s surgery. We’ve been closely monitoring the swelling, and there’s no denying it’s become quite significant.

original: Saturday we took connor to firemans park, thinking that the fireman's easter egg hunt was to start at 11am. It turned out it was on the friday. Thank goodness i brought a bag of eggs with me just incase. So connor had a great time finding eggs out in the park. Sunday morning when he woke up he was so excited that the easter bunny had come. There is nothing better then to see the excitement on your childs face. After egg hunting, we all went to church. Even though the 'easter bunny' is fun and all. We do make sure our kids know the true meaning of the holidays. This was megan's first easter, she looked so cute dressed in her jean dress and stockings :)
polished:
On Saturday, we brought Connor to Fireman's Park, believing the fire department's Easter egg hunt would begin at 11 AM. To our surprise, the event had actually taken place the day before. Fortunately, I had packed a bag of eggs just in case, so Connor still enjoyed hunting for them throughout the park.  

When Sunday morning arrived, his face lit up with pure joy upon discovering the Easter Bunny's visit. Few moments compare to witnessing such heartfelt excitement in your child's eyes. After our egg hunt festivities, we attended church together—while we embrace the fun traditions, we also ensure our children understand the holiday's true significance.  

This Easter marked Megan's very first celebration, and she looked absolutely adorable in her denim dress and stockings. A weekend filled with laughter, love, and cherished family moments.

polished:
**November 22, 2002**  

What a day! My new boots—the Face Boots and Tredair Flame Boots—finally arrived, but they were delivered to my house instead of work. Now I have to wait four more agonizing hours to get them. Ugh!  

To top it off, I somehow ended up with a flat tire. Fortunately, I’m at work, and my coworkers are helping me out. They’ll inflate it first to see if it holds air. If not, they’ll swap it with my full-sized spare. Looks like I might be shopping for a new tire tonight—hello, Hamad Tire!  

Oh, and I almost forgot—I thought I’d stumbled upon another VW, but no such luck. Still, today’s been quite the adventure!

original: I know in a previous post i protected parents, almost even taking their side, well here's my little change of mind. Parents don't know anything. They think they know you soooo well, maybe even to the point where they can read emotions off your face. They can't. Parents know nothing about us. And when i go upstairs after arguing with nicole about kelli, like i just did a few minutes ago, and they want me to tell them what's wrong. Yeah, how about you shut the fuck up!? i don't have to tell you what's wrong all the time. Here's the situation with nicole and kelli. Kelli and nicole don't like each other. At all.
polished:
**Revised Version:**  

While I previously defended parents—even leaning toward their perspective—I’ve since reconsidered. The truth is, parents often believe they understand us completely, convinced they can decipher every emotion we display. But they don’t. In reality, they know very little about who we truly are.  

Take tonight, for example. After arguing with Nicole about Kelli, I retreated upstairs, only to be met with intrusive questions about what was wrong. Honestly? I don’t owe them an explanation for everything. The situation is simple: Nicole and Kelli can’t stand each other. That’s all there is to it.

**Morning Commute Chronicles & A Surprising Discovery**

While I didn’t think it was my most polished piece, apparently someone disagreed. A funny little reminder of the internet’s unpredictability.

original: Pears and peanut butter attempt #2. I have hard pears this time, and my own jar of peanut butter which i can dip the pears into, but it is still crunchy peanut butter not smooth and i definitely think it makes a difference. I am also slightly perturbed as i thought this was a healthy snack and have just noticed that per 5th of a jar (and our jars are way smaller) as in per 100g there are 614 calories!!!!!!!!!! don't think about it. Have just got back from an evening out at my old music teacher/friend's house. Yes i know... I missed er for that- but i did tape it! have also discovered that they are showing repeats of series 9 every morning at 9:55! was good seeing my friend, strange but good.
polished:
**Second Attempt with Pears and Peanut Butter**  

This time, I opted for firm pears and my personal jar of peanut butter for dipping. However, I’m using the crunchy variety instead of smooth, and I can tell the texture makes a noticeable difference.  

To my dismay, I initially believed this to be a healthy snack—until I checked the nutritional label. A mere 100g (about a fifth of our small jar) contains a staggering 614 calories! Best not to dwell on that...  

Earlier, I returned from a lovely evening at the home of an old friend who also happens to be my former music teacher. Yes, I missed *her*—but I recorded it! As a bonus, I discovered that reruns of Series 9 are airing daily at 9:55 AM.  

It was wonderful catching up, albeit a bit surreal. All in all, a good day.

original: Urllink some people are jumping to connect urllink this dot : the urllink organization for security and cooperation in europe was invited to monitor the election by the state department. The observers will come from the osce's office for democratic institutions and human rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a u.s. Presidential election. With urllink this dot : a baker's dozen of congressional democrats, among them four new yorkers, has petitioned u.n. Secretary- general kofi annan to dispatch international observers to florida to oversee this year's presidential balloting there. I humbly disagree. Based on the info available, the osce seems to be coming here to learn from the u.s. Election process, not to oversee it, which was the original partisan and childish call for u.n.
polished:
"The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) was invited by the U.S. State Department to observe the upcoming presidential election. The monitoring team, drawn from the OSCE’s Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights, marks the first time such international observers will be present for a U.S. election.  

Meanwhile, a group of thirteen congressional Democrats—including four representatives from New York—has formally requested that U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan deploy international monitors to Florida to oversee the voting process. However, I respectfully disagree with this proposal. Available information suggests that the OSCE’s role is to study the U.S. electoral system rather than to supervise it—a distinction that renders the earlier call for U.N. intervention both politically motivated and unnecessary.

original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished:
**GOP Faces Backlash Over Controversial Voter Registration Tactics at Naturalization Ceremony**  

Following widespread criticism, naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville will be relocated after reports emerged that GOP activists improperly registered new citizens as Republicans without their consent.  

The June 29 ceremony proceeded as usual, with nearly 200 individuals proudly becoming U.S. citizens. However, as the event concluded, an immigration official directed attendees to a voter registration table—a common practice at such ceremonies. What set this table apart was its overt partisan slant: Republican volunteers distributed forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked, effectively enrolling new voters into the GOP without their explicit approval.  

Among those disturbed by the tactic was Linda Cross, who attended to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath. The incident has sparked scrutiny over ethical boundaries in voter recruitment efforts, prompting authorities to reconsider the venue for future ceremonies.  

—Reported by Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy

original: I have always prided myself in making anyone that frequents casa pescatore as comforable as possible. I want them to make sure they feel at home as they will feel in their prospective residence. Yesterday- i hope i succeeded. The masses all congregated on perry ave with what many consider ' extreme prejudice'. 4:30pm was the time my best friend eric and his son nunu came over with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set and i had all the food that i cooked and the bells were ringing crazy. Before i could blink - my best friend from florida walked through the door and that made me smile. I missed that motherfucker so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She is expecting and this is the closest i could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.
polished:
At Casa Pescatore, my greatest joy has always been ensuring every guest feels as comfortable and welcome as they would in their own home. Yesterday, I believe I achieved that. The neighborhood gathered on Perry Avenue with an enthusiasm some might call overwhelming. At 4:30 PM, my dearest friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived, bearing a massive pan of baked ziti. The tables were meticulously arranged, laden with my homemade dishes, while laughter and chatter filled the air like joyous bells.  

Then, in a moment that warmed my heart, my closest friend from Florida walked through the door—a reunion I’d longed for. His presence alone was a gift, but the delightful surprise was his wife joining him. With her expecting a child, this is the nearest I’ll come to unclehood, and I embraced the role wholeheartedly. I showered her with endless trays of food and tiramisu, savoring every second of their company.

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished:
The notion of criminalizing flag desecration struck me as intriguing—perhaps even a potential defense against accusations of witchcraft. As an international blogger, I’ve generally hesitated to engage in certain cultural debates, especially those involving national symbols. However, having initiated this discourse (the conversation itself, not the act of burning flags), I feel compelled to share my perspective.  

Fundamentally, legislating against flag-burning is absurd. When we grant any symbol—regardless of its significance—such unquestioning veneration and legal safeguarding, we inch dangerously closer to authoritarianism. Symbols are inherently mutable; their power lies not in their intrinsic value but in the meanings we ascribe to them or impose upon them.

I am not quite sure what will be happening here; whether i will take to it and whatnot, but since i spend so much of my time in front of a machine, i might as well make proper use of my time and post all these bits of craziness that whiz around, nay stumble around more like, in my head. I was insipired by a blogger (who i never met in person), who managed to keep us up to date in the most intimate fashion about her day to day existance, and somewhat entertained at the same time...
polished: Embarking on this blogging journey feels both exciting and uncertain—I still haven't seen how my blog will ultimately take shape, but this seems like the right place to begin. While I'm unsure whether this endeavor will truly resonate with me, given how much of my life unfolds in front of a screen, I might as well channel that time productively by sharing the whirlwind of thoughts—or perhaps more accurately, the stumbling fragments of ideas—that occupy my mind. My inspiration comes from an anonymous blogger whose vivid, intimate chronicles of daily life captivated and entertained me, proving how powerful personal storytelling can be.

original: 1. Everyone is obsessed with one movie or series of movies, what's yours? evil dead series.. If it wasn't obvious. (i have one of the largest 'stuff from that movie series' collections ever) 2. Can you play an instrument? what is it? bass guitar, oh yes, i rock out. 3. Biggest money wasting vice? either my compulsive buying of dvds or any new technology. 4. Have any phobias, allergies, or compulsive behaviors? no, no, and i must bank-face all moneys in my wallet in order from least to greatest at all times. 5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? because i said so.
polished:
1. If I had to pick one film franchise that completely captivates me, it would undoubtedly be the *Evil Dead* series—though my massive memorabilia collection probably makes that obvious.  

2. Music is a passion of mine, and I proudly wield a bass guitar—because nothing beats the thrill of rocking out.  

3. My biggest financial weakness? Either my endless DVD purchases or my insatiable craving for the latest tech gadgets.  

4. No phobias or allergies here, but I do have one quirk: every bill in my wallet *must* be neatly arranged from smallest to largest denomination.  

5. And as for the timeless woodchuck riddle—well, the answer is simple: because I said so.

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. However, i think too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it was not particularly gripping, and i don't feel like i gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, i thought the score was poor, and was basically a knock-off of the gladiator. The gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman and it worked b/c it backed up and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.
polished: Tonight, I watched *Troy* with my family, but the film failed to leave a lasting impression. While it certainly had potential, the production seemed overly focused on its grandiose set design—though visually stunning—at the expense of a compelling narrative and cohesive themes. The retelling of the story lacked depth, leaving me emotionally uninvested and ultimately unfulfilled. Character development was notably underwhelming, further diminishing the film's impact. The score, unfortunately, felt derivative, echoing *Gladiator*'s haunting vocals without achieving the same emotional resonance. In *Gladiator*, the mournful backdrop enhanced an already gripping tale, but here, it merely highlighted the film's narrative shortcomings.

original: Urllink lets all give a big hello to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block, urllink pulpfiction 1.0 from urllink freshly squeezed software . It looks like it has a lot of native app goodness. It should be noted that it is not free or free, since that seems to be a 'hot topic' on the interweb again. You can try it for 15 days and then go back to something else, or pony up $25 if you like it. A feature that jumps out at me right away is how each post is its own entity, and can be moved around, stored, labeled, and even deleted. I could easily see how this would make some news tracker type people very happy. It imports and exports opml, as you might expect.
polished:
Introducing PulpFiction 1.0 – the innovative Atom/RDF/RSS reader from Freshly Squeezed Software. This powerful application delivers a premium desktop experience with robust native functionality. Notably, PulpFiction operates on a commercial model (currently priced at $25), though a 15-day trial period allows users to evaluate its capabilities risk-free.  

Among its standout features is the unique post management system, where each entry functions as an independent element that can be organized, categorized, archived, or removed with ease – a particularly valuable tool for news monitoring professionals. The application maintains standard interoperability through comprehensive OPML import/export support, ensuring seamless workflow integration.

original: Today... I miss my sister terribly - it just seems strange not to have her hanging around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though it was only for a week, she really made her presence felt, and i mean that in a good way. Just doing the scrapbook for our trtip to tasmania brings fond memories of a time past recently - last week in fact. Maybe it's just the thought that i won't see her for quite a while - with her going to bristol in sept/oct and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a link to my family back home. Oh how i miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?
polished: Today, I feel an overwhelming sense of longing for my sister—her absence leaves an unexpected void. Though her stay was brief, just a week, she filled our home with warmth and lively energy (even her playful teasing, which I secretly cherished). As I work on our Tasmania trip scrapbook, each page floods me with vivid, joyful memories from what now feels like a distant past—though it was merely days ago. Perhaps this ache stems from knowing our next reunion is far off, with her move to Bristol looming in September or October. More than just companionship, she was my tangible connection to family and home—a reminder of all I hold dear. Tomorrow marks the beginning of a new term, and I can’t help but wonder: how did these fleeting holidays slip through my fingers so soon?

original: Ever have one of those days when you just don't know what the... What the... Anything? no? well then you should skip the rest of this because it won't make any sense to you. To those of you choosing to continue on i offer the following observation. ' sometimes i wish i'd been given the manual .' manuals, if done correctly at least, let you know: what things are for, what they can do, how they do the things they do, what happens if you push button x or y, what to do if things aren't doing what they're supposed to the phone number and email address of the omniscient guru who can solve every problem very useful information. Unfortunately i didn't get a manual with me.
polished:
Have you ever experienced one of those utterly bewildering days when nothing seems to make sense? If not, consider yourself fortunate—you may as well stop reading now, as this won't resonate with you. But for those who persist, here's a thought I often ponder: "Sometimes I wish life came with an instruction manual."  

A well-crafted manual, after all, provides clarity: it explains purpose, functionality, and mechanics. It outlines the consequences of pressing button X or Y, troubleshoots malfunctions, and even supplies the contact details of an all-knowing expert ready to resolve any issue. Such guidance would be invaluable.  

Alas, no such manual accompanied my existence.

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished: There’s certainly nothing wrong with PCs—if I were a dedicated gamer with ample time, I’d undoubtedly own a high-end PC to enjoy the vast library of available titles. However, beyond a handful of standout exceptions, the overwhelming selection at stores like CompUSA quickly begins to feel repetitive. Initially, the sheer volume is impressive, but upon closer inspection, most games are merely slight variations on familiar themes—first-person shooters, mystery adventures, strategy titles, and simulations. The countless iterations of *Age of Empires* border on absurdity: *Age of Empires* with orcs, *Age of Empires* in space, *Age of Empires* featuring fuzzy wombats. It’s reminiscent of those endless movie trailers that all open with the same tired line: *"In a world..."*

original: Lblair (non-privileged).pst -----original message----- from: threet, kay sent: thursday, june 28, 2001 11:08 am to: blair, lynn cc: stevens, bob; neville, sue; cabrera, reyna subject: nsp powerpac issues lynn, following our discussion yesterday afternoon, reyna and i came back and reviewed the nsp powerpac agreement. We were specifically looking for language in this agreement which may require us to true up for the customer regardless of whether or not we were allocating storage on a given gas day. We couldn't put our finger on any language in the current agreement (dated april 1, 2001) that requires us to true up for them, but perhaps we overlooked or misinterpreted something.
polished:
**Subject:** Clarification Request on NSP PowerPac Agreement Terms  

**From:** Kay Threet  
**Sent:** Thursday, June 28, 2001, 11:08 AM  
**To:** Lynn Blair  
**Cc:** Bob Stevens, Sue Neville, Reyna Cabrera  

Dear Lynn,  

Following our conversation yesterday afternoon, Reyna and I conducted a thorough review of the NSP PowerPac Agreement. Our focus was to identify any contractual language that might obligate us to reconcile adjustments ("true up") for the customer, irrespective of whether storage allocation occurred on a specific gas day.  

After careful examination of the current agreement (dated April 1, 2001), we were unable to locate any explicit provisions mandating such reconciliations. However, to ensure comprehensive accuracy, we wanted to confirm whether we might have missed or misinterpreted any relevant clauses.  

Your insights on this matter would be greatly appreciated.  

Best regards,  
Kay Threet

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished:
**Subject:** Urgent Concern Regarding PX Day-Ahead Auction Disruptions Due to ISO Rule Changes  

**Date:** Monday, December 11, 2000  
**To:** All PX Market Participants  
**From:** John Yurkanin, Chief Operating Officer  

Dear Market Participants,  

The California ISO's emergency tariff filing last Friday has significantly disrupted the PX Day-Ahead Auction market. The simultaneous implementation of soft and hard caps has created a fundamental disconnect, exposing all participants to unacceptable risks. Furthermore, these changes are unlikely to achieve the ISO's intended reduction in real-time energy sales and procurement.  

As a result, supply resources will continue prioritizing the ISO's higher-priced real-time opportunities. To address this issue, the PX is formally requesting that Terry Winter of the ISO authorize immediate adjustment bids for all submitted schedules at market-relevant prices.  

We appreciate your attention to this critical matter and will keep you informed of further developments.  

Best regards,  
John Yurkanin  
Chief Operating Officer

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

**Subject:** Update on BPA Control Area Reserves for Grays Harbor and Willamette  

Dear Team,  

I wanted to ensure you’ve reviewed Les Rawson’s communication regarding Grays Harbor and Willamette.  

Effective immediately, Enron has secured Control Area Reserves service from BPA. This arrangement permits the sale of unit-contingent energy as hourly firm, given that BPA will provide reserves for up to 60 minutes.  

**Action Required:**  
- If Grays Harbor Paper notifies RT of a unit derate or outage, RT must promptly inform BPA Dispatch.  
- The schedule reduction should be implemented during the next ramp period.  

**Example Scenario:**  
If Grays Harbor’s unit trips at 13:33, RT must notify BPA and adjust the schedule to zero for the 14:00 interval.  

**Key Takeaway:**  
BPA will maintain the schedule for a maximum of 60 minutes.  

Best regards,  
Bill

original: Cstclai.nsf ---------------------- forwarded by carol st clair/hou/ect on 05/05/2000 04:11 pm --------------------------- carol st clair 04/26/2000 04:41 pm to: rod nelson/hou/ect@ect cc: subject: deutsche bank rod: here are their credit issues: 1. In the cross-default language that want to add language that basically says that even if a cross-default occurs, unless the non-defaulting determines in good faith that performance by the defaulting party of its obligations under the master is "endangered", then no cross default is triggered. 2. In credit event upon merger we had commented that instaed of the "materially weaker" standard we wanted to specify that it meant being rated below bbb- by s&p. Do you feel strongly about this?
polished:
**Revised Memorandum**  

**From:** Carol St. Clair  
**Date:** April 26, 2000  
**To:** Rod Nelson  
**CC:** [Relevant Parties]  
**Subject:** Deutsche Bank Credit Terms  

Rod,  

Please find below the key credit-related concerns for Deutsche Bank:  

1. **Cross-Default Clause Amendment**  
   They propose revising the cross-default language to clarify that a default will only be triggered if the non-defaulting party, acting in good faith, determines that the defaulting party’s ability to fulfill its obligations under the master agreement is genuinely at risk.  

2. **Credit Event Upon Merger**  
   Regarding our previous discussion on the "materially weaker" standard, we suggested replacing it with a specific rating threshold—namely, a downgrade below BBB- by S&P. Do you have any strong objections to this adjustment?  

Best regards,  
Carol St. Clair  

*Forwarded by Carol St. Clair on May 5, 2000, at 4:11 PM*

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished:
El Paso Natural Gas Initiates Market Assessment for Pipeline Expansion Amid California Capacity Crisis  

Following overwhelming demand in its previous open season—where bids for 14.4 Bcf/d far exceeded the 1.2 Bcf/d of firm transportation capacity offered—El Paso Natural Gas has launched a new open season to gauge market interest in a mainline expansion. This move also addresses regulatory concerns over severe capacity constraints at the California border, where soaring demand and record-high prices have intensified pressure on the pipeline to act.  

In a January 3 communication, Daniel M. Adamson, Director of FERC’s Office of Energy Projects, explicitly urged El Paso to adapt its Line 2000 project to alleviate the critical strain on California’s gas market. The directive underscores the urgency of infrastructure enhancements to meet the state’s escalating energy needs.

original: Sscott5.nsf ahimsa (uh-him-sah) noun the principle of noninjury to living beings. [sanskrit ahimsa : a-, not + himsa, injury (from himsati, he injures).] "as my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, i became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The lines in the anthem: scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa." m.k. Gandhi, the story of my experiments with truth, 1927. Today is october 2, the day mohandas karamchand gandhi was born in the year 1869. A man born some two centuries ago may appear irrelevant to our age, but in reality his life and message are still applicable to our lives today.
polished:
**Ahimsa: The Timeless Principle of Nonviolence**  

*Ahimsa* (Sanskrit: अहिंसा, pronounced *uh-him-sah*) is the ethical doctrine of refraining from harm to all living beings. Derived from the Sanskrit roots *a-* (not) and *himsa* (injury), it embodies compassion in thought, word, and deed.  

As Mahatma Gandhi reflected in *The Story of My Experiments with Truth* (1927), his deepening understanding of *ahimsa* led him to scrutinize even his innermost thoughts and expressions. He found lines like *"Scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks"* deeply at odds with his commitment to nonviolence.  

Born on October 2, 1869, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi may seem a figure of a distant past, yet his teachings on peace, justice, and *ahimsa* remain profoundly relevant in our modern world. His legacy endures as a guiding light for humanity.

Polanco is a democrat and is currently suffering through a personal scandal and as a result, it is reported that his political career is essential dead. Polance is planning to run for mayor of los angeles rather than run for another senate term. ? the bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, beginning today or tomorrow. polished:
---  

**Subject ** Legislative Update on SoCal MOU Bill  

Governor Davis and Senator Polanco reached an informal agreement over the weekend, in which Polanco has committed to sponsoring the Southern California Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) bill. Polanco, a Democratic senator currently embroiled in a personal scandal, is widely believed to be at the end of his political career. Rather than seeking re-election to the Senate, he intends to pursue a mayoral bid in Los Angeles.  

The bill is anticipated to be introduced in the newly convened extraordinary session, with proceedings expected to begin imminently. Once introduced, it will first be referred to the Senate Energy Committee. However, given that Committee Chair Senator Bowen is a staunch opponent of the MOU, the bill is likely to face prolonged deliberations in committee. Extended negotiations and amendments could further delay its progress, increasing the risk of a Southern California bankruptcy.  

---  

This version improves clarity, structure, and professionalism while preserving the original meaning. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished:
**Subject:** CFTC Approval of NYMEX Rule 6.40C – Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants  

**Date:** October 3, 2000  
**To:** All NYMEX and COMEX Members  
**From:** Neal L. Wolkoff, Executive Vice President  

**Notice No.:** 00-338  

Dear Members,  

We are pleased to inform you that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) has officially approved the implementation of **NYMEX Rule 6.40C** ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants"). The rule, which is now in effect, is attached for your reference.  

This new regulation aligns with a recent CFTC advisory, granting Futures Commission Merchants (FCMs) the authority—under specified conditions outlined in the rule—to utilize their proprietary internal systems for generating **Average Price (AP) calculations** when processing orders or series of orders with multiple price points.  

Should you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact our office.  

Best regards,  
**Neal L. Wolkoff**  
Executive Vice President
