*(Reference for fellow music fans: Steve Miller Band’s “Take the Money and Run” – fitting for this situation!)*

original: Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :d this puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large branching map. This game is quite amusing and running through it to complete the game was quite a bit of fun. ^_^ it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements though. To get all the cubes you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher. These can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking into a guide (*raises hand* i gave up. -_-). The guide, 'a complete guide to fez!!!'
polished: Who could resist the charm of sporting a fez? :) This delightful puzzle-platformer follows the adventures of a small, fez-wearing protagonist as they gather fragments to reconstruct a cube while exploring an expansive, interconnected world. The game offers a thoroughly enjoyable experience, with its engaging gameplay making completion a genuine pleasure. ^_^ However, the pursuit of all cubes and achievements may test your patience. Unlocking every cube requires solving intricate codes—some decipherable in moments, while others might push you to consult a walkthrough (*raises hand in defeat* -_-). For those moments, "A Complete Guide to FEZ!!!" proves invaluable.

original: It's not hard for me to see why other people like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing i have a vive and i'm much more interested in playing room sized games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe inspiring in the scale of its universe, but i also felt that same scale was a hinderence to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too large for me. Perhaps if i were more patient and had more time for gaming this would be compelling to me. But i don't have either and there are plenty more vr games i'd rather spend my time on.
polished: While I can certainly understand why many players enjoy this game, it ultimately didn’t resonate with me. As a Vive owner, I’m naturally drawn to immersive, room-scale experiences that utilize motion controllers—something this title doesn’t prioritize. Initially, the vastness of its universe is breathtaking, but I soon found that same scale became more of an obstacle than an asset. The steep learning curve and the significant time investment required to reach engaging content early on proved overwhelming for my preferences. Admittedly, with greater patience and more gaming time at my disposal, I might have found it captivating. However, given my current constraints and the wealth of other compelling VR options available, this simply wasn’t the right fit for me.

original: Hands down my favorite first person shooter of all time. Run and gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload half-way through your magazine all the time then you will have a pouch full of half full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you have caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.
polished: Without question, this stands as the most exceptional first-person shooter I've ever experienced. It demands tactical precision rather than reckless run-and-gun gameplay. The weapon mechanics showcase remarkable realism—rifle rounds to vital areas like the chest, neck, or head prove instantly lethal unless merely grazing the target. Projectiles follow authentic ballistic trajectories with noticeable bullet drop, requiring disciplined burst fire to maintain accuracy. The ammunition system mirrors reality; frequent tactical reloads leave you with partially spent magazines rather than an endless supply. Stamina plays a crucial role—prolonged sprinting impairs your aim as your character struggles for breath, forcing strategic pacing. The game rewards proper firing positions, offering stability bonuses when bracing your weapon on surfaces or going prone, while standing shots remain inherently less precise. This is a shooter that truly respects the principles of combat realism.

original: Let me start off by saying i did not purchase eu when it first came out and that i got it on sale which included ew so i never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game however, it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for xcom2 i love it, the game plays pretty well for me on medium and i am running a gtx560 with 2gb of vram. At first the game set it to high and it was running a bit sluggishly but not to the point of being unplayable but when i dropped it down to medium it smoothed on out. Not sure if i am just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they are coming from some really entitled people.
polished:
Allow me to begin by clarifying that I didn't purchase XCOM: Enemy Unknown upon its initial release. Instead, I acquired it during a sale that included the Enemy Within expansion, which means I missed the technical issues some players reported. That said, I thoroughly enjoyed the game—its challenging early stages made eventual successes particularly rewarding.  

Moving on to XCOM 2, I'm thoroughly impressed. The game runs smoothly on medium settings on my system, which features a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game defaulted to high settings, resulting in minor performance hiccups—nothing game-breaking, but noticeable. After adjusting to medium, the experience became seamless.  

I can't say whether I've simply been fortunate with game performance, but many of the negative critiques I've encountered come across as overly demanding rather than reflective of genuine flaws. The game delivers a compelling experience when properly optimized.

original: +rpg levelling +wide-variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humored -grind intensive (if under utilizing the civvy station types) -sub-par ai teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of levelling skills (that is, no branching) listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses up there, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and still really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to increase the life of this game is the mods. Fight for universe is easily the star, but big fight for beef is also very good.
polished:
**Refined Version:**  

This space RPG delivers an exhilarating experience with its engaging leveling system, diverse ship selection, and realistic physics-driven movement for both vessels and projectiles. The resource management is intuitive yet rewarding, complemented by a dash of dark humor. While the game avoids excessive grinding when utilizing civilian stations effectively, it does suffer from lackluster AI allies, limited equipment options, and a linear skill progression without branching paths.  

That said, don’t let the drawbacks fool you—this game is an absolute blast. Despite its shortcomings, it offers surprising depth in strategy and variety. The pacing is brisk from the start and only intensifies as you progress. Even with restricted equipment choices, the thrill of unlocking new ships and advancing skills keeps the excitement alive. To truly extend its replay value, mods are essential—*Fight for Universe* stands out as a masterpiece, with *Big Fight for Beef* also delivering a stellar experience.

original: World leaders gather to face uncertainty more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the swiss mountain resort davos for the annual world economic forum (wef). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from china's economic power to iraq's future after this sunday's elections. Uk prime minister tony blair and south african president thabo mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the wef are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The brazilian city of porto alegre will host the rival world social forum, timed to run in parallel with the wef's ritzier event in davos.
polished:
Global dignitaries convene amid geopolitical tensions as the World Economic Forum commences in Davos. Over 2,000 influential figures from business and politics worldwide are descending upon the prestigious Swiss alpine retreat for this year's pivotal summit. From January 23-27, attendees will engage in critical dialogues spanning China's growing economic influence to post-election scenarios in Iraq following this weekend's pivotal vote.  

The high-profile gathering boasts participation from more than 20 heads of state, including UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki. Notably, this year's proceedings are expected to unfold without the disruptive protests that have characterized past forums, as anti-globalization activists have canceled planned demonstrations.  

Meanwhile, in a symbolic counterpoint, Porto Alegre, Brazil, will serve as the stage for the alternative World Social Forum—a parallel event designed to challenge the elite discourse of Davos with grassroots perspectives on global equity.

original: Deadline nears for fiat-gm deal fiat and general motors (gm) have until midnight on 1 february to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to gm, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. Gm, whose own european operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent fiat shares down 1.2% on tuesday, after monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The us firm is thought to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by fiat's decision to sell off fiat's finance arm and halve gm's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between gm and daimlerchrysler to ally with fiat.
polished:
**Time Running Out for Fiat-GM Negotiations as Key Deadline Looms**  

Fiat and General Motors (GM) face a critical deadline of February 1st at midnight to resolve their ongoing dispute regarding a potential acquisition. This cutoff date signifies the moment Fiat gains the contractual right to sell its automotive division to GM—a provision established under their 2000 partnership agreement.  

GM, grappling with financial losses in its European operations, has sought to avoid absorbing Fiat’s unprofitable automotive unit. Market sentiment shifted this week as reports of stalled negotiations drove Fiat’s stock down 1.2% on Tuesday, erasing part of Monday’s 4% surge fueled by hopes of a lucrative settlement.  

Sources indicate GM has proposed approximately $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to terminate the alliance. The automaker contends that Fiat’s divestment of its finance division and dilution of GM’s stake through a capital increase invalidated the original agreement.  

The 2000 partnership emerged from a competitive bid between GM and DaimlerChrysler to secure an alliance with the Italian automaker. Now, with hours remaining, the fate of this long-standing deal hangs in the balance.

original: Cardinal criticises iraq war cost billions of pounds spent on conflict in iraq and in the middle east should have been used to reduce poverty, cardinal cormac murphy-o'connor has said. The head of the catholic church in england and wales made the comments on bbc radio 4 and will re-iterate his stance in his christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a christmas message to denounce the war in iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the archbishop of canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on bbc radio 4's thought for the day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history poverty".
polished:
Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, has strongly condemned the Iraq War as a catastrophic misuse of resources that could have alleviated global poverty. In a pointed Christmas message delivered during his Midnight Mass and reiterated on BBC Radio 4's *Thought for the Day*, the Cardinal lamented how billions of pounds spent on Middle Eastern conflicts had been diverted from urgent humanitarian needs.  

Joining the Archbishop of Canterbury in voicing opposition to the war, Cardinal Murphy-O'Connor described the military expenditure as "a terrible waste" while millions worldwide suffer from extreme poverty, malnutrition, and preventable diseases. He called for 2005 to become a turning point in the fight against global inequality, urging concerted efforts to "make poverty history" through targeted campaigns and moral leadership.

original: British stars denied major oscars british hopes of winning major oscars were dashed as uk stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, mike leigh's vera drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards and there was no prize for star imelda staunton. Kate winslet also lost to best actress hilary swank, while clive owen and sophie okonedo failed to win best supporting actor awards. The uk's andrea arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows number 73 and motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow uk nominees gary mckendry and ashvin kumar.
polished:
British Talent Overlooked at Major Oscar Ceremony  

The 77th Academy Awards proved disappointing for British contenders, as none secured victories in the top acting or directing categories. Mike Leigh's critically acclaimed *Vera Drake*, despite receiving three nominations, missed out on both Best Director and Best Original Screenplay honors, while its lead actress Imelda Staunton was also left unrecognized.  

In the highly competitive Best Actress race, Kate Winslet was ultimately surpassed by Hilary Swank, and Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo similarly fell short in their respective supporting categories. However, the UK did celebrate one triumph: Andrea Arnold claimed the Oscar for Best Live Action Short Film with her raw and poignant drama *Wasp*.  

Arnold, a former children's TV presenter from the 1980s, described the win as "completely overwhelming." Her film, a stark portrayal of a struggling single mother, prevailed over submissions by fellow British filmmakers Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar. While the evening marked a setback for British cinema in major categories, Arnold's victory offered a silver lining for the UK film industry.

original: Halloween writer debra hill dies screenwriter and producer debra hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic halloween, has died in los angeles aged 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred jamie lee curtis as a babysitter terrorised by a psychopath. Directed by john carpenter, it made over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with carpenter on escape from new york and the fog. Born in new jersey, hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly taken by men.
polished:
Renowned screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, celebrated for her seminal contributions to the 1978 horror masterpiece *Halloween*, has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54 after a battle with cancer. A trailblazer in the film industry, Hill co-wrote the iconic slasher film alongside director John Carpenter, launching Jamie Lee Curtis to stardom in her breakout role as a babysitter hunted by a masked killer. The groundbreaking thriller shattered box office records, earning over $60 million globally—an unprecedented achievement for an independent production at the time.  

Hill’s creative partnership with Carpenter extended to cult classics like *Escape from New York* and *The Fog*, cementing her legacy in genre filmmaking. Hailing from New Jersey, she rose through the ranks of Hollywood, starting as a production assistant before ascending to roles as an assistant director and second-unit director—a remarkable feat in a male-dominated era. Widely recognized as a pioneering figure for women in cinema, Hill defied industry norms, carving a path for future generations of female filmmakers in an overwhelmingly male landscape. Her visionary work continues to inspire the horror genre and independent filmmaking at large.

original: Broadband fuels online expression fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by uk think-tank demos. It said that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the uk have broadband and that number is growing fast. The demos report looked at the impact of broadband on people's net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.
polished:
**The Digital Revolution: How High-Speed Internet is Transforming Online Engagement**  

Research indicates that broadband connectivity is revolutionizing how individuals interact online, fostering unprecedented levels of digital self-expression. A study by the UK-based think tank Demos reveals that 25% of British broadband users actively publish content and maintain personal websites, underscoring the profound influence of instant, high-speed access.  

The report highlights how always-on, rapid connections are reshaping internet behavior, with over five million UK households now subscribed to broadband—a figure rising steadily. Findings show that more than half of broadband users access the web before breakfast, while one in five admit to late-night browsing sessions. Most notably, broadband is empowering users to transition from passive consumers to active participants, fundamentally altering the digital landscape.

original: Yukos heading back to us courts russian oil and gas company yukos is due in a us court on thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by russian authorities in order to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the us, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, yuganskneftegas. The unit was however sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated us bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.

Yukos Returns to U.S. Courts in Battle for Survival  

The embattled Russian oil and gas giant Yukos is set to appear before a U.S. court this Thursday as part of its ongoing struggle to avoid collapse. Facing a staggering $27 billion tax claim, the company is being dismantled by Russian authorities.  

In a strategic move, Yukos sought U.S. bankruptcy protection, aiming to leverage international legal frameworks to block the forced sale of its crown jewel—the Yuganskneftegas oil production unit. Despite these efforts, the unit was ultimately acquired by state-owned Rosneft for $9.4 billion, though not before the auction faced significant disruptions.  

Yukos and its legal team now contend that the sale violated U.S. bankruptcy statutes. The company and its principal shareholders have pledged to pursue all available legal avenues against any entities involved in acquiring its assets, signaling an unrelenting fight for justice.

original: Chinese dam firm 'defies beijing' the china three gorges project corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the chinese state press has said. The builder of the three gorges dam is continuing work on the sister xiluodu dam, said the beijing news. The xiluodu dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction projects called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The beijing news said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the three gorges underground power plant and the three gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by china's state environmental protection agency (sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.
polished:
**Chinese Dam Builder Challenges Government Directive**  

The China Three Gorges Project Corporation is reportedly defying a government mandate to suspend construction on its massive Xiluodu Dam, according to state media reports. Despite a nationwide halt imposed on 30 major infrastructure projects due to inadequate environmental reviews, the state-owned firm—best known for constructing the Three Gorges Dam—continues work on the Xiluodu project.  

*Beijing News* revealed that the corporation may opt to pay a penalty rather than cease operations. Additionally, the company has disregarded stoppage orders at two other sites: the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Electrical Power Supply Plant.  

China’s State Environmental Protection Administration (SEPA) had flagged these projects for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments. However, as of now, only 22 of the 30 non-compliant projects have adhered to the shutdown directive.

original: Man city 0-2 man utd manchester united reduced chelsea's premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over manchester city. Wayne rooney met gary neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off richard dunne, to put united ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate dunne hooked a volley over david james' head and into his own net. Steve mcmanaman wasted city's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes united had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a paul scholes header over the bar.
polished:
Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premier League advantage to nine points with a hard-fought 2-0 victory over Manchester City at the Etihad Stadium. The breakthrough came when Wayne Rooney cleverly redirected Gary Neville's cross at the near post, with the ball taking a decisive deflection off Richard Dunne to beat David James. The City defender's misfortune continued seven minutes later as he inadvertently volleyed the ball over his own goalkeeper's head for United's second. 

Despite dominating possession, City squandered their best opportunity when Steve McManaman fired wide from point-blank range in the first half. United initially struggled to impose themselves, displaying more effort than finesse in their build-up play during the opening period. Paul Scholes' wayward header represented their only genuine chance before the interval in what appeared to be an unconvincing performance from Sir Alex Ferguson's side. However, their second-half resurgence ultimately secured three crucial points in their pursuit of league leaders Chelsea.

original: Wales 'must learn health lessons' the new health minister for wales says there are lessons to learn from england in tackling waiting lists. Dr gibbons, who was a gp in blaengwynfi, in the upper afan valley, before becoming am for aberavon, said nhs staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". **Polished Version:**  

The newly appointed Health Minister for Wales, Dr. Brian Gibbons, has emphasized the need to learn from England’s strategies in addressing healthcare waiting lists. On his inaugural day in office following the dismissal of Jane Hutt, Dr. Gibbons acknowledged significant challenges but affirmed that the foundational elements for progress remain intact.  

However, opposition parties, including Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, have called for a shift in policy under his leadership. In her defense, Ms. Hutt highlighted her tenure’s broader achievements, asserting that waiting times constituted merely 10% of the overall health agenda.  

Before assuming his ministerial role, Dr. Gibbons served as a general practitioner in Blaengwynfi, located in the Upper Afan Valley, and later as the Assembly Member for Aberavon. He noted that NHS staff are seeking stability after years of extensive transformation and restructuring.  

Among the most pressing issues during Ms. Hutt’s five-and-a-half-year tenure as Wales’ inaugural Health Minister was the persistent challenge of lengthy waiting lists—a key concern that continues to shape the healthcare debate.

original: Ferguson hails man utd's resolve manchester united's alex ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at aston villa. original: Singer's film to show at festival a documentary which takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer george michael will be shown at this year's berlin film festival. polished:
**Polished Version:**  

*A revealing documentary chronicling the extraordinary life of global music icon George Michael will premiere at this year’s Berlin Film Festival. Titled *A Different Story*, the film will be featured in the festival’s Panorama section, running from February 10–20.  

The intimate portrait delves into Michael’s meteoric rise from his Wham! beginnings to his evolution as a solo superstar, while also shedding light on his personal struggles, legal disputes with Sony, and his outspoken activism against the Iraq War and American policies.  

Michael himself will attend the festival on February 16 to introduce the screening, joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. Spanning 93 minutes, the documentary offers an unfiltered glimpse into the artist’s journey, blending rare insights with pivotal moments from his legendary career.*

original: Downloads enter us singles chart digital music downloads are being included in the main us singles chart for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green day's boulevard of broken dreams is currently number two in billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the uk singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the us are already used to compile billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to us radio stations which play chart music.
polished:
For the first time, digital music downloads have been integrated into the prestigious US Singles Chart, marking a significant evolution in how Billboard's Hot 100 rankings are calculated. This groundbreaking change combines download sales—previously tracked separately—with traditional physical single sales and radio airplay data to create a more comprehensive measure of a song's popularity.  

Currently, Green Day's *Boulevard of Broken Dreams* holds the No. 2 spot on Billboard's Pop Chart while leading the Digital Chart. A similar shift is expected in the UK Singles Chart later this year, following the US model.  

Billboard has also introduced a second new ranking, the Pop 100, which merges digital and physical sales with airplay data—though it exclusively considers radio stations that feature chart-topping tracks. This dual expansion reflects the growing influence of digital music in shaping industry trends.

original: Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard the net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott richter, the man behind optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into chapter 11. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems but still keep trading. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog spamhaus, optinrealbig was sued in december 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by microsoft and new york attorney general eliot spitzer who alleged that mr richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.
polished:
The long arm of anti-spam legislation has finally caught up with one of the internet's most notorious offenders. Scott Richter, the self-proclaimed "Spam King" behind OptInRealBig.com, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection following mounting legal pressure. His company, responsible for flooding inboxes with billions of unsolicited emails, claims the bankruptcy filing will allow continued operations while addressing multiple lawsuits—most significantly a multi-million dollar case brought by Microsoft.

Ranked as the world's third-largest spam operation by anti-spam organization Spamhaus, OptInRealBig first faced legal action in December 2003. Microsoft joined forces with then-New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer to prosecute Richter for massive violations of anti-spam regulations. The case revealed Richter's network had exploited 514 compromised IP addresses across 35 countries to distribute billions of illegal spam messages. This landmark litigation demonstrates how aggressive enforcement can hold even the most prolific spammers accountable for their actions.

original: Arnesen denies rift with santini tottenham sporting director frank arnesen has denied that coach jacques santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at white hart lane. "there is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. "he has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." arnesen said he was unable to throw any light onto the problems that caused santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But i trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.
polished:
Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has firmly dismissed rumors of a personal conflict with former coach Jacques Santini being the reason for his abrupt resignation. Recent media reports had suggested Santini felt his authority was being undermined by Arnesen's influence at White Hart Lane.  

Speaking to BBC Radio Five Live, Arnesen stated, "These claims are completely unfounded. Jacques resigned solely due to private matters—it had nothing to do with any professional disagreements. He personally assured me that his decision was entirely his own."  

When pressed for details on Santini's sudden departure after only 13 matches in charge, Arnesen admitted he had no further insight. "Jacques never disclosed the specifics, and I respect his privacy. We must accept his decision with understanding and dignity," he added.

original: Ireland surge past scots ireland maintained their six nations grand slam ambitions with an impressive victory over scotland at murrayfield. original: Warning over tsunami aid website net users are being told to avoid a scam website that claims to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam e-mail that is currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text bears all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterises many other phishing attempts.

**Public Alert: Beware of Fraudulent Tsunami Relief Website**  

Internet users are being warned to steer clear of a deceptive website falsely claiming to collect donations for tsunami victims. The fraudulent site mimics an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage, lending it an air of legitimacy. However, the DEC has confirmed it has no affiliation with the fake platform and has reported the matter to law enforcement.  

This scam is among numerous others exploiting public sympathy following the tsunami tragedy. The malicious link is distributed via a widely circulating spam email with the subject line *"Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal."* The message contains telltale signs of phishing, including grammatical errors and misspellings typical of such fraudulent schemes. Authorities urge vigilance to prevent falling victim to these exploitative tactics.

original: Iraq to invite phone licence bids iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, saying it wants to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, arab and foreign companies, iraq's ministry of communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the iraqi telecommunications and post company (itpc). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry said that it wanted to increase iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." it also hopes to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunication sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 february. It also is planning a road-show for investors in amman, jordan.
polished:
**Iraq Announces Tender for Telecommunications Licenses to Expand National Coverage**  

The Iraqi government has announced plans to issue two new telecommunications licenses, aiming to dramatically improve nationwide connectivity over the next ten years. The Ministry of Communications has opened the bidding process to local, Arab, and international firms, with the selected operators partnering with the state-owned Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC).  

The winning companies will be responsible for deploying and managing a fixed-line network, delivering voice, fax, and broadband services across the country. The ministry emphasized its goal of raising Iraq's telephone service penetration rate from the current 4.5% to approximately 25% within a decade. Additionally, the initiative seeks to establish a dynamic and competitive telecommunications sector.  

Further details regarding the tender process will be released on the ministry's official website on February 9. A dedicated investor roadshow is also scheduled to take place in Amman, Jordan, to attract potential bidders.

original: More women turn to net security older people and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect pcs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, for net security firm preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diversity of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, that has gone up by an average of 13.2%. But more retired women (53%) were buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband net connections can pose to surfers.
polished:
A recent two-year study reveals a significant shift in internet security trends, with older adults and women increasingly taking proactive measures to safeguard their home computers against cyber threats. Research conducted for cybersecurity firm Preventon indicates that female consumers purchasing antivirus, anti-spam, and anti-spyware solutions showed an annual growth rate of 11.2% from 2002 to 2004.

The findings demonstrate that cybersecurity awareness campaigns are effectively reaching diverse online populations. Notably, retirees now account for 40% of home security software purchases, with this demographic growing at an average annual rate of 13.2% over the past three years. Among senior citizens, women lead in cybersecurity adoption, comprising 53% of purchases compared to their male counterparts.

This research highlights evolving user demographics and challenges traditional stereotypes about internet usage patterns. It also underscores the heightened security risks associated with high-speed broadband connections, which appear to be driving greater security consciousness across all age groups and genders.

original: Podcasts mark rise of diy radio an apple ipod or other digital music players can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more ipod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former mtv host and vj (video jockey) adam curry. Podcasting takes its name from the apple ipod, although you do not need an ipod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is basically an internet-based radio show which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a pc, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.
polished:
The emergence of podcasting has revolutionized the audio landscape, ushering in a new era of DIY radio production. While modern digital music players like Apple's iPod boast impressive storage capacities—capable of holding up to 10,000 songs—an increasing number of users are dedicating this space to diverse audio content crafted by an eclectic range of creators. This phenomenon, known as podcasting, has found its most vocal champion in Adam Curry, the former MTV host and video jockey.

Though the term derives from the iPod brand, podcasting isn't exclusive to Apple's device—neither production nor consumption requires specific hardware. At its core, podcasting represents internet-based radio programming, typically produced in home studios with minimal equipment: just a microphone, personal computer, and basic editing software. Creators simply upload their content to the web, making it freely accessible for global audiences to download and enjoy at their convenience. This democratization of audio broadcasting has opened unprecedented opportunities for creative expression and information sharing.

original: Levy takes whitbread novel prize orange prize winner andrea levy has seen her book small island win the whitbread novel of the year award. She is now favourite to win the overall prize after beating booker winner alan hollinghurst's the line of beauty. Geraldine mccaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for not the end of the world. All the category winners go through to compete for the whitbread book of the year title, which carries with it a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges including sir trevor mcdonald, actor hugh grant and writer joanne harris will meet up on 25 january to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker william hill has placed london-based levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.
polished:
**Andrea Levy Triumphs at Whitbread Awards with "Small Island"**  

Acclaimed author Andrea Levy, already an Orange Prize winner, has secured the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award for her celebrated work *Small Island*. This victory positions her as the frontrunner for the prestigious Whitbread Book of the Year title, surpassing even Booker Prize winner Alan Hollinghurst’s *The Line of Beauty*.  

In another notable achievement, Geraldine McCaughrean claimed the Children’s Fiction Award for the third time with *Not the End of the World*. Each category winner now advances to the final round, vying for the ultimate honor and a £25,000 prize.  

The judging panel, featuring distinguished figures such as Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and novelist Joanne Harris, will convene on January 25th to deliberate, with the grand winner announced later that evening. Bookmakers William Hill have already tipped Levy’s London-set novel as the favorite at 6/4 odds.

original: Yukos seeks court action on sale yukos will return to a us court on wednesday to seek sanctions against baikal finance group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue baikal and others involved in the sale of yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' us lawyers will attempt to have baikal assets frozen after the russian government ignored a us court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that baikal - which bought the yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on sunday at a state provoked auction - has strong links with surgutneftegas, russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.
polished:
Yukos to Pursue Legal Action Against Baikal in U.S. Court Over Asset Sale  

Yukos will appear before a U.S. court this Wednesday to request sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure entity that acquired its primary asset. The embattled oil company has announced plans to sue Baikal and other parties involved in the $20 billion sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking substantial damages.  

This legal move follows the Russian government's disregard for a U.S. court injunction issued last week to halt the auction. Yukos' American legal team will now push for a freeze on Baikal's assets.  

The origins and intentions of Baikal remain shrouded in mystery. Russian media reports suggest the firm—which secured Yuganskneftegas for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles) in a state-orchestrated auction—has close ties to Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer. The circumstances surrounding the acquisition continue to raise questions about transparency and legitimacy.

original: Hearts 2-1 livingston hearts wrapped up their scottish cup quarter-final tie against livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over colin meldrum and into the net from a jamie mcallister free kick. Mcallister himself scored the second when he met saul mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour but hearts held on. The opening goal came after gus bahoken had clumsily fouled miller 35 yards from goal. Mcallister floated the free kick into the livi box and miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where mcallister raced in to head past meldrum.
polished:
Hearts secured a commanding 2-1 victory over Livingston in the Scottish Cup quarter-finals, delivering an explosive start with two early goals. The match ignited within the first minute as Lee Miller capitalized on Jamie McAllister's precision free-kick, soaring above the defense to nod a looping header past goalkeeper Colin Meldrum. McAllister then turned scorer just nine minutes later, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' pinpoint cross at the far post to extend Hearts' dominance. Despite a contentious second-half header from Craig Easton, the hosts maintained their composure to seal the win.  

The breakthrough came after Gus Bahoken's rash challenge on Miller 35 yards out. McAllister's expertly delivered set-piece found Miller, who outmaneuvered Livingston's stagnant backline to guide his effort over Meldrum. Hearts' relentless pressure continued, and Mikoliunas' blistering run down the right flank set up McAllister for a clinical finish, leaving Livingston with too much ground to recover.

original: Sun offers processing by the hour sun microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service which will allow customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company which believes that computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said sun's chief operating officer jonathan schwartz. "why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked in a webcast launching sun's quarterly network computing event in california.
polished:
Sun Microsystems has revolutionized access to high-performance computing with its innovative pay-per-use grid service. The company now enables businesses to tap into massive computational resources at an unprecedented value—just $1 per hour for processing and storage capabilities hosted on Sun's infrastructure.  

This groundbreaking approach to grid computing represents a paradigm shift in how enterprises view IT resources, positioning computing power as a fundamental utility alongside traditional hardware and software. Sun's leadership draws a compelling parallel between this model and the evolution of electricity distribution, suggesting that on-demand computing could follow a similar trajectory as essential public utilities.  

"Instead of investing in costly private infrastructure, why not leverage our grid for just a dollar an hour?" challenged Jonathan Schwartz, Sun's Chief Operating Officer, during the unveiling at the company's quarterly Network Computing event in California. This bold proposition underscores Sun's vision of making enterprise-grade computing accessible, scalable, and economically efficient for businesses worldwide.

original: Jamieson issues warning to bigots scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the scottish executive campaign against sectarianism. She praised celtic and rangers for their work in tackling the problem. However, the minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective. Ms jamieson was speaking ahead of the third round scottish cup clash between the glasgow clubs at parkhead on sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week ms jamieson and first minister jack mcconnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.
polished:
Scotland's Justice Minister Cathy Jamieson has issued a stern warning to sectarian football fans, vowing to target their passion by imposing match bans as part of a broader crackdown on bigotry. In her address prior to this weekend's high-profile Scottish Cup clash between Celtic and Rangers at Parkhead, Jamieson emphasized that exclusion orders form a crucial element of the Scottish Executive's anti-sectarianism initiative.

The minister commended both Glasgow clubs for their ongoing efforts to address the deep-rooted issue while stressing that eliminating sectarian abuse surrounding Old Firm matches remains a top priority. This renewed focus comes after Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell recently convened with fan representatives from both clubs to tackle the persistent problem that has long tarnished Scottish football's reputation. The government's determined stance signals an unprecedented commitment to eradicating the toxic bigotry that has historically plagued certain segments of these rival fanbases.

polished:
Hollywood luminaries Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth graced the red carpet at the UK premiere of *Beyond the Sea* in London's Leicester Square on Thursday evening. Spacey, 45, not only stars in the biographical drama but also serves as its writer and director, bringing to life the extraordinary story of legendary 1950s crooner Bobby Darin.  

"*Beyond the Sea* is my heartfelt homage to a truly extraordinary artist," Spacey remarked, embodying Darin’s persona so fully that he performs all 18 tracks on the film’s soundtrack. Meanwhile, Bosworth, 21, portrays Darin’s real-life wife, Hollywood icon Sandra Dee.  

"Before this project, I was completely unfamiliar with Bobby Darin’s legacy, but now I’m utterly captivated by his brilliance," shared Bosworth, who arrived at the premiere alongside her British partner, actor Orlando Bloom. original: Home phones face unclear future the fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, more than 45 million people in the uk, germany, us and south korea now only use a mobile. It showed that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles and to friends. In the uk 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.
polished:
The traditional landline telephone may soon become obsolete as mobile devices increasingly dominate personal communications. Nokia's recent research reveals a significant global shift, with over 45 million consumers across the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now relying exclusively on mobile phones. While some households retain landlines due to lower call costs, the overwhelming consensus indicates mobile technology represents the future of telephony.  

The study highlights distinct usage patterns between the two platforms: landlines remain preferred for lengthy conversations, whereas mobile calls tend to be brief and primarily between friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents acknowledged still using fixed-line services for cost efficiency, yet this practicality appears insufficient to reverse the broader trend toward mobile adoption. As convenience and technological advancements reshape communication norms, the fate of home phones grows increasingly uncertain.

original: Melzer shocks agassi second seed andre agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by jurgen melzer in the quarter-finals of the sap open. Agassi was often bamboozled by the austrian's drop shots in san jose, losing 6-3 6-1. Defending champion and top seed andy roddick rallied to beat sweden's thomas enqvist 3-6 7-6 (8-6) 7-5. But unseeded cyril saulnier beat the fourth seed vincent spadea 6-2 6-4 and tommy haas overcame eighth seed max mirnyi 6-7 (2-7) 7-6 (7-3) 6-2. Melzer has now beaten agassi in two of their three meetings. "i had a good game plan and i executed it perfectly," he said. "it's always tough to come out to play andre. "i didn't want him to play his game. He makes you run like a dog all over the court."
polished:
In a stunning upset at the SAP Open quarter-finals, unseeded Austrian Jurgen Melzer delivered a commanding performance against second-seeded legend Andre Agassi, securing a decisive 6-3, 6-1 victory. Melzer's strategic use of drop shots left Agassi struggling throughout the match in San Jose. Meanwhile, defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick mounted an impressive comeback against Sweden's Thomas Enqvist, prevailing 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5 in a hard-fought battle.  

The tournament saw further surprises as unseeded Cyril Saulnier dominated fourth-seeded Vincent Spadea with a 6-2, 6-4 win, while Tommy Haas overcame eighth-seeded Max Mirnyi in a thrilling three-setter, 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2.  

With this victory, Melzer now leads Agassi 2-1 in their head-to-head meetings. Reflecting on his triumph, Melzer remarked, "I had a solid game plan and executed it flawlessly. Facing Andre is always a challenge—I knew I had to disrupt his rhythm. He’s the kind of player who forces you to cover every inch of the court.

original: Mps tout lords replacement plan a group of mps has tried to raise the pressure on tony blair over reform to the house of lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. Mps and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditaries lost their seats. The group says it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the lords. Tony blair has argued. There needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions there will be proposals for changing at least the powers of the lords in labour's manifesto.
polished:
**A Cross-Party Coalition Proposes Sweeping Reforms for the House of Lords**  

A coalition of MPs has intensified pressure on Prime Minister Tony Blair to advance House of Lords reform by presenting a comprehensive blueprint for modernization. The cross-party group has introduced draft legislation outlining a streamlined second chamber, with 70% of its members elected democratically.  

Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers were stripped of their seats, Parliament has struggled to reach consensus on further reform. The group now asserts it can secure backing to eliminate the remaining 92 hereditary members—a move previously delayed by the government due to anticipated resistance in the Lords.  

Blair has emphasized the necessity of broad agreement before enacting reforms. Meanwhile, speculation persists that Labour’s upcoming manifesto may include proposals to curtail the Lords' powers, signaling potential progress in this long-debated issue.

original: Disappointed scott in solid start allan scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's european indoor championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the jose m cagigal memorial meeting in madrid. "it was definitely a learning curve and i certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the east kilbride athlete. The race was won by felipe vivancos, who equalled the spanish record. Sweden's robert kronberg was second, with haiti's dudley dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first iaaf indoor grand prix circuit final.
polished:
Allan Scott remains optimistic about his medal prospects at the upcoming European Indoor Championships despite a bittersweet debut on the international stage. The 22-year-old Scottish hurdler secured fourth place in the 60m event at Madrid's prestigious José M. Cagigal Memorial Meet, marking his inaugural appearance on the global circuit.  

"While it was undoubtedly a valuable learning experience, I'm still fully committed to contending for a podium finish next week," stated the East Kilbride sprinter.  

The race was dominated by Spain's Felipe Vivancos, who matched the national record, followed by Sweden's Robert Kronberg in second and Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Though Scott clinched his heat with a time of 7.64 seconds, a marginal 0.04-second slowdown in the final left him with mixed feelings about his performance. Nevertheless, his strong showing has only reinforced his determination to excel at the championships.

original: Us woman sues over cartridges a us woman is suing hewlett packard (hp), saying its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from georgia says that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer that it needs re-filling even when it does not. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the us who has purchased an hp inkjet printer since february 2001. Hp, the world's biggest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. Hp ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. But the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

A Georgia woman has filed a class-action lawsuit against Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging that the company deliberately programs its printer ink cartridges to deactivate prematurely. According to the complaint, an embedded microchip falsely signals that the cartridge is empty, forcing users to replace it even when ink remains. The lawsuit aims to include all U.S. consumers who purchased HP inkjet printers since February 2001.  

HP, the global leader in printer manufacturing, has declined to address the allegations. While the company states that its cartridge chips are designed to monitor ink levels and prompt timely replacements, the lawsuit contends that these chips are also programmed to disable cartridges on a preset expiration date, irrespective of actual ink supply.

**Virgin Radio Pioneers Global 3G Broadcasting**  

UK-based Virgin Radio has announced a groundbreaking initiative to become the world’s first radio station to deliver content via 3G mobile networks. In collaboration with technology partner Sydus, the broadcaster will extend its reach across select 2G and high-speed 3G platforms.  

Starting later this year, audiences will gain access to the service by downloading dedicated software from Virgin Radio’s official website. James Cridland, Virgin Radio’s Head of New Media, emphasized the significance of this innovation, stating, *“This positions radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution.”*  

The initial rollout will feature Virgin Radio’s flagship station, followed by its digital counterparts, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Cridland added, *“With this app, listeners worldwide can enjoy Virgin Radio anytime, anywhere—right from their mobile devices.”*  

This milestone marks a transformative step in mobile broadcasting, reinforcing Virgin Radio’s commitment to cutting-edge audio delivery.

polished:
**Polished Version:**  

Roxy Music has been announced as part of the lineup for this year’s Isle of Wight Festival, joining acts such as Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The three-day event, scheduled for June 10–12, will feature R.E.M. as headliners.  

The legendary band’s original members—Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson—are set to perform on the festival’s Saturday night. Currently, the group is also recording new material in the studio, marking their first release since their 1982 album *Avalon*.  

Formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno—with Manzanera joining a year later—Roxy Music rose to fame with their 1972 hit *Virginia Plain*. Their chart-topping discography includes classics like *Street Life*, *Love Is the Drug*, and their 1981 cover of John Lennon’s *Jealous Guy*.

Four Six Nations captains, including Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, will lead the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid match on March 5, joining forces for a noble cause. The star-studded lineup also features France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami. original: Spirit awards hail sideways the comedy sideways has dominated this year's independent spirit awards, winning all six of the awards for which it was nominated. The critically acclaimed comedy *Sideways* swept this year’s Independent Spirit Awards, securing all six honors for which it was nominated. The film claimed the coveted title of Best Feature, while director Alexander Payne triumphed with dual wins for Best Director and Best Screenplay, sharing the latter accolade with co-writer Jim Taylor. The ensemble cast further elevated the film’s success, with Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen each earning acting awards.  

With five Academy Award nominations, *Sideways* is poised for potential Oscar glory this Sunday. Celebrating its 20th anniversary, the Spirit Awards recognize outstanding achievements in cinema produced beyond the confines of major studios and are traditionally held on the eve of the Oscars.  

Among other notable winners was Catalina Sandino Moreno, honored as Best Actress for her riveting portrayal of a drug courier in the Colombian drama *Maria Full of Grace*. Moreno also carries her momentum into the Oscars, where she is nominated in the same category. Joshua Marston received the Best First Screenplay award for his work on *Maria Full of Grace*, rounding out the evening’s distinguished honorees.

polished:
In 2004, Prince reigned supreme as the highest-earning musician, surpassing industry icons like Madonna and Elton John, according to *Rolling Stone* magazine's annual rankings. The legendary artist amassed an impressive $56.5 million (£30.4 million) through his *Musicology* tour, album sales, and publishing royalties. Madonna secured the second spot with $54.9 million (£29.5 million), fueled by her ambitious *Re-Invention* world tour. Meanwhile, the iconic duo Simon & Garfunkel claimed tenth place, generating $24.9 million (£13.4 million) from their highly anticipated reunion tour.  

*Rolling Stone* noted Prince's triumphant return to the spotlight after years of relative obscurity in the mainstream music scene. His 2004 tour alone grossed $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales, while his latest album, *Musicology*, sold 1.9 million copies, cementing his resurgence as a dominant force in the industry.

original: Blue beat u2 to top france honour irish band u2 have been honoured at france's biggest music awards, but were beaten to a prize by boy band blue. polished: At France's prestigious NRJ Music Awards, legendary Irish rock band U2 received a special recognition for their outstanding career achievements, though they were unexpectedly surpassed by British pop group Blue for the International Group honor. The ceremony, held in Cannes, saw American ensemble Maroon 5 claim dual victories as Best New International Artist and for their chart-topping single "This Love." original: Wal-mart fights back at accusers two big us names have launched advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behaviour. Wal-mart kicked off the battle with adverts in newspapers like the wall street journal, using an open letter from company president lee scott saying it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth". "there are lots of 'urban legends' going around these days about wal-mart, but facts are facts.
polished:
**Corporate Giants Launch PR Offensive to Counter Criticism**  

Two major U.S. corporations have initiated high-profile advertising campaigns to address public scrutiny and clarify misconceptions about their business practices. Walmart, the world’s largest retailer, has responded to mounting criticism regarding its compensation policies, employee benefits, and career advancement opportunities by placing over 100 full-page advertisements in leading national newspapers.  

Simultaneously, pharmaceutical giant Eli Lilly is preparing a campaign to refute what it deems misleading allegations about its flagship product, Prozac.  

Walmart’s aggressive public relations strategy began with prominent ads in publications like *The Wall Street Journal*, featuring an open letter from CEO Lee Scott. The letter emphasized the company’s commitment to transparency, urging the public to consider the "unfiltered truth" behind the retailer’s operations. "While numerous myths about Walmart continue to circulate," Scott wrote, "the facts remain undeniable."  

Both corporations aim to reshape public perception by directly confronting detractors and reinforcing their corporate narratives.

original: Tories outlining policing plans local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. Party leader michael howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He said the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The lib dems said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while labour criticised "extravagant" tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the police federation of england and wales, which represents rank and file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained. Jan berry said: "it is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. "these plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned.
polished: The Conservative Party has proposed a new policing initiative that would empower local communities to directly elect their neighborhood police commissioners. Unveiled by party leader Michael Howard, this plan aims to replace what he described as "overly bureaucratic" police authorities while maintaining the existing role of chief constables. However, the proposal has drawn criticism from multiple fronts. The Liberal Democrats expressed concerns about potential extremist influence over local policing, while Labour dismissed the scheme as another example of Conservative overpromising. Jan Berry, Chair of the Police Federation of England and Wales, emphasized the critical need to preserve operational independence in law enforcement. "Policing is a vital public service, not a political bargaining chip to be exploited during election cycles," Berry cautioned. "There's a real danger these reforms could enable ideologically driven individuals to improperly influence frontline policing decisions." The Federation, representing frontline officers across both nations, stressed the importance of keeping law enforcement free from partisan interference.

original: At a glance: tory health checks the uk' opposition conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: people coming to live and work in britain from outside the eu. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with lots of tb, they would have to have a chest x-ray and further tests if appropriate. All people from outside the european union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical. Tuberculosis, hepatitis b and hiv. A positive test for tb would automatically mean visa applications being turned down. All other conditions would be dealt with on a case by case basis.
polished:
**UK Conservatives Propose Mandatory Health Screenings for Immigrants**  

The UK's opposition Conservative Party has announced plans to implement comprehensive health checks for immigrants should they win the upcoming general election. Key details of the proposed policy include:  

- **Targeted Screening:** Individuals relocating to the UK from outside the European Union for work or residence will be subject to medical evaluations. Those arriving from high-risk tuberculosis (TB) regions intending to stay six months or longer must undergo mandatory chest X-rays, with additional tests if necessary.  
- **Extended Stay Requirement:** All non-EU nationals applying to reside in the UK for a year or more will be required to complete a full medical examination.  
- **Focus on Infectious Diseases:** Screenings will prioritize detecting TB, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB diagnosis will result in automatic visa rejection, while other medical conditions will be assessed individually.  

This initiative aims to safeguard public health while ensuring a structured approach to immigration policy.

original: Paris promise raises welsh hopes has there been a better six nations match than saturday's epic in paris? and can the welsh revival continue all the way to a first grand slam since 1978? those are the two questions occupying not just wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in paris. Welsh legend mervyn davies, a member of two of three grand slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn williams, wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games i have ever played in". polished:
**A Parisian Promise Ignites Welsh Dreams**  

Has the Six Nations ever witnessed a more thrilling spectacle than Saturday’s unforgettable clash in Paris? And can Wales sustain this remarkable resurgence to claim their first Grand Slam in over four decades? These burning questions now captivate not only Welsh supporters but the entire rugby world, following a breathtaking performance that left fans in awe.  

Mervyn Davies, a titan of Welsh rugby and veteran of two Grand Slam-winning teams in the 1970s, hailed the match as "one of the finest displays in the last thirty years." Martyn Williams, whose two tries sealed Wales' triumph, described it as "among the most extraordinary games I’ve ever been part of." Meanwhile, a dejected Bernard Laporte, France’s coach, could only reflect: "The match belonged to France in one half—and to Wales in the other.

**Manchester's Doves Claim UK Album Chart Crown with "Some Cities"**  

Manchester rock trio Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their latest release, *Some Cities*, dethroning the flamboyant American act Scissor Sisters. The album's success follows their hit single *Black and White Town*, which previously peaked at number six.

polished:
Welsh rugby star Mefin Davies appears set to continue his career with Gloucester Rugby, despite attracting attention from the Ospreys. The 32-year-old hooker, who delivered a standout performance in Wales' recent Six Nations victory over England, is reportedly content with his current club. original: Cabinet anger at brown cash raid ministers are unhappy about plans to use whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government minister nick raynsford has acknowledged. Mr raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. But he said local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in england keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr raynsford said nearly all central government departments had an interest in well run local authorities.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

The Cabinet has expressed frustration over Chancellor Gordon Brown's decision to redirect £512 million from central government funds to local budgets, a move revealed in his recent pre-budget report. Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford acknowledged the discontent among ministers, admitting to holding "frank discussions" regarding the proposal.  

Despite the controversy, Raynsford emphasized that local authorities must maintain high-quality services without imposing significant council tax hikes. The reallocated funds form part of a broader £1 billion initiative aimed at capping next year’s council tax increases below 5%—a critical measure ahead of an anticipated general election.  

Raynsford further noted that nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in ensuring efficient local governance, underscoring the broader implications of the funding shift.

original: Israeli club look to africa four african players, including zimbabwe goalkeeper energy murambadoro, are all ready to play for israeli club hapoel bnei sakhnin in the uefa cup. The club have a strong ethic and are high profile promoters of peace and co-operation within israel.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin, an Israeli football club with a historic presence as the first Arab team to compete in European tournaments, has bolstered its roster with four African talents, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, for their upcoming UEFA Cup campaign. Their first-round fixture pits them against England’s Newcastle United, marking a significant milestone in the club’s journey.  

Murambadoro, who rose to prominence during the Africa Cup of Nations in Tunisia, played a pivotal role in Bnei Sakhnin’s dominant 6-1 victory over Albania’s Partizani Tirana in the previous qualifying round. The goalkeeper recently joined the Israeli side after a short spell with South Africa’s Hellenic FC.  

Based in the town of Sakhnin, near Haifa, the club has earned recognition not only for its on-field success—culminating in last season’s Israeli Cup triumph—but also for its unwavering commitment to fostering peace and unity within Israel’s diverse society. With a reputation built on integrity and inclusivity, Bnei Sakhnin continues to stand as a beacon of cooperation in the world of sports.

original: New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University college london research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety as mps are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert professor richard allsop, says cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the uk's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 department of transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.
polished:
**Revised Version:**  

A groundbreaking study reveals that reducing the legal blood alcohol limit for drivers could save significantly more lives than previously estimated. According to research conducted by University College London, lowering the current limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would prevent approximately 65 fatalities annually.  

The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, coincide with upcoming parliamentary debates on the government’s Road Safety Bill. While the proposed legislation addresses penalties for speeding offenses, it does not currently include revisions to drink-driving limits.  

Transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, who led the study, highlights that adopting the stricter limit would also result in 230 fewer serious road injuries each year compared to 2003 data. This change is projected to yield annual economic savings of £119 million for the UK.  

Earlier assessments, such as a 1998 Department of Transport report, had suggested a potential annual reduction of 50 lives under similar measures—underscoring the new study’s more substantial projected benefits.

original: This paper presents a millimeter-scale cmos 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This obviates the need for using power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype asic is fabricated in tsmc 65 nm lp cmos process and consumes the average static power of 0.535 mw under 1.2 v analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 mev proton beam setting.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

This study introduces a compact, millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 array detector designed for precise single-charged-particle monitoring in external beam cancer radiotherapy. Each pixel incorporates a 1×1 µm² diode to quantify energy deposition within the depletion region, while the collective array achieves an expansive 512×512 µm² active detection area. Departing from conventional voltage-drop sensing, the system employs pulse-width measurement—tracking the duration for voltage recovery to baseline—eliminating reliance on bulky, high-power analog-to-digital converters. Fabricated in TSMC’s 65 nm LP CMOS process, the prototype ASIC demonstrates robust functionality with a mere 0.535 mW static power consumption at 1.2 V supply. Successful validation in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam confirms its operational efficacy for radiotherapy applications.

original: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (avs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that avs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize avs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (so) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (ue) seeking avs and human-driven vehicles (hvs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering mixed fleet of avs and hvs.
polished: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) demonstrate significant potential to mitigate the inefficiencies caused by selfish routing behaviors in transportation networks. However, existing approaches often presume AVs will passively comply with centralized routing directives—an assumption that lacks practical feasibility.
